## Why Reverse Scoring?

Questionnaires often include **negatively worded items** to:

- Reduce response bias
- Check if participants are paying attention
- Balance the scale

**Example:**

- Positive: "I am the life of the party"
- Negative: "I don't like to draw attention to myself"

---

## The Problem

If someone scores **5** (strongly agree) on both:

- "I am outgoing" → High extraversion ✓
- "I prefer to be alone" → High extraversion? ✗

We need to **reverse** the negative item before summing!

---

## The Formula

For a **1-5 scale**:

$$\text{reversed} = 6 - \text{original}$$

| Original | Reversed |
|----------|----------|
| 1 | 5 |
| 2 | 4 |
| 3 | 3 |
| 4 | 2 |
| 5 | 1 |

---

## Why 6?

The formula is: `(max + min) - original`

For a 1-5 scale: `(5 + 1) - original = 6 - original`

For a 1-7 scale: `(7 + 1) - original = 8 - original`

---

## In Our Data

Items `G1`, `G3`, `G5`, and `G6` are negatively worded and need reverse scoring.

```{webr-r}
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read.csv(data_url, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Look at G1 values
head(data$G1)
```

---

## Creating Reversed Columns

```{webr-r}
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read.csv(data_url, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Reverse score G1, G3, G5, and G6
data$rev_G1 <- 6 - data$G1
data$rev_G3 <- 6 - data$G3
data$rev_G5 <- 6 - data$G5
data$rev_G6 <- 6 - data$G6

# Check it worked
head(data[, c("G1", "rev_G1")])
```

---

## Verifying the Reversal

The original and reversed should sum to 6:

```{webr-r}
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read.csv(data_url, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

data$rev_G1 <- 6 - data$G1

# Check: do they sum to 6?
head(data$G1 + data$rev_G1)
```

---

## Creating Subscale Scores

The Grit Scale has two subscales. Sum items using **reversed** versions:

```{webr-r}
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read.csv(data_url, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

data$rev_G1 <- 6 - data$G1
data$rev_G3 <- 6 - data$G3
data$rev_G5 <- 6 - data$G5
data$rev_G6 <- 6 - data$G6

# Consistency of Interest (G1, G3, G5, G6 - all reversed)
data$consistency <- data$rev_G1 + data$rev_G3 + data$rev_G5 + data$rev_G6

# Perseverance of Effort (G2, G4, G7, G8 - no reversing needed)
data$perseverance <- data$G2 + data$G4 + data$G7 + data$G8

head(data[, c("consistency", "perseverance")])
```

---

## Common Mistake!

Using the **original** items instead of **reversed**:

```r
# WRONG! Using G1 instead of rev_G1
data$wrong_consistency <- data$G1 + data$G3 + data$G5 + data$G6
```

Always double-check you're using `rev_` versions for G1, G3, G5, and G6!
